[{'created': '2019-09-26 09:30:11.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I124692cf622fe6e3b4fda20729f217cb8ea19336
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I124692cf622fe6e3b4fda20729f217cb8ea19336

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-30 14:05:24.000000000', 'message': "Ensure pod IP is retrieved from annotation

We are retrieving the pod IP from a nonexistent annotation
field, when should be from the annotations in the pod metadata.
Also, when this information is not present we keep retrying with
the same pod object, which doesn't contains an annotation
causing the controller restart.

Closes-Bug: 1845635
Change-Id: I04095a7d36219175c09d4503f2347ab035d3e242
(cherry picked from commit 9dfc5a1dd36e7c1691f5fbcfe9ec506f8dc5d2b9)
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure pod IP is retrieved from annotation

We are retrieving the pod IP from a nonexistent annotation
field, when should be from the annotations in the pod metadata.
Also, when this information is not present we keep retrying with
the same pod object, which doesn't contains an annotation
causing the controller restart.

Closes-Bug: 1845635
Change-Id: I04095a7d36219175c09d4503f2347ab035d3e242
(cherry picked from commit 9dfc5a1dd36e7c1691f5fbcfe9ec506f8dc5d2b9)

Are you responsible for django 2.2 support in designate-dashboard?'}, {'account_id': 29313, 'date': '2019-10-07 06:38:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> question: Does this complete djnago 2.2 supportr in
 > designate-dashboard?
 > I hope a volunteer (or assignee) for django 2.2 per horizon plugin
 > do everything for Django 2.2 support.
 > Are you responsible for django 2.2 support in designate-dashboard?

Yes. This patch fully supports the django2.2 in the designate-dashboard. I cannot recall anything left to add in here. I am open to more suggestions/feedback.
As per our Ussuri goals, we have to add django2.2 support in horizon plugins. Also, I have reviewed a couple of patches for the same and could provide great help to achieve this as I am aware of most of the gate failures for these jobs. commit_message:
Use Horizon project template for django jobs

Horizon defined a project template 'horizon-non-primary-django-jobs'
for django jobs. This patch use that template to run django jobs
here. For information please refer [1]

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/681969/

Change-Id: I32a39fd2bde587a9891dea288026cc4518e89068

commit_message:
DIB: do not mention dhcp-all-interfaces explicitly

It's a dependency of the ironic-python-agent-ramdisk element, so
it will be included anyway.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/684304
Change-Id: Id47b8ff78506a15045cf31a5f619649a0b3147ed

DIB: add non-voting image building jobs for various distros

This way we can track if image building still works on them.

commit_message:
Remove @safe_connect from put_allocations

The only user of put_allocations of the report client is
heal_allocations. It is easy to remove the @safe_connect decorator
from put_allocations as heal_allocations already handles
PlacementAPIConnectFailure exception.

This patch changes heal_allocations to raise
PlacementAPIConnectFailure instead of relying on @safe_connect.

Change-Id: I6b3f61525883a019703cf564e693516b3b61febc

[{'created': '2019-09-23 19:38:47.000000000', 'message': 'Remove use of nested curly braces

This is not valid syntax and should not be used. The inner braces are
not evaluated on future ansible versions leading to incorrect behaviour.

Change-Id: I19354738c101f104a90eed7745e4a0ea0f23ddd3
'}]
commit_message:
Remove use of nested curly braces

This is not valid syntax and should not be used. The inner braces are
not evaluated on future ansible versions leading to incorrect behaviour.

Change-Id: I19354738c101f104a90eed7745e4a0ea0f23ddd3

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ic3ac2c8ba0ce546fc5654650ac6f5c9b533bdc04

commit_message:
Make sure subports are unique when removing them

Neutron cares about subports of the trunk being unique. This commit
makes sure that is true when removing them by applying `set()` to list
of removed subports.

Change-Id: I6f55fe4e25e5956d758e7da84eb8eb172c8cd585
Closes-Bug: 1847287
(cherry picked from commit 9172f378e00a7fd9355b7f959ea367e49ddc85a5)

SG of a LBaaS that would map to a SVC without selector, as this
kind of SVC is not wired by Kuryr. Also, we shouldn't try to update

commit_message:
Ensure no LBaaS SG update is triggered for SVCs without selectors and ports

When a Network Policy is enforced we shouldn't try to update the
SG of a LBaaS that would map to a SVC without selector, as this
kind of SVC is not wired by Kuryr. Also, we shouldn't try to update
the LBaaS SG when no ports are defined in the SVC spec.

Closes-Bug: 1845917
Change-Id: I94a288f2b66bd2444d177931f509e1b6ef250235
(cherry picked from commit 68145b9b589f27b2db0130e6671c54c15f844bc6)

commit_message:
Ensure vif handler retry in case of missing ns resources

This patch ensure the on_present event of the vif handler is retried
if all the resources related to the namespace where the pod belongs
are not yet created.

Change-Id: I1345cafffdd98077d23fd8b761c9527ff6316956
Closes-Bug: 1847085
(cherry picked from commit 5a4c7f2eab9ac098acc105752b84b1b1fcee55d2)

subject: Ensure ports from pool do not reference deleted SGs/NPs
messages: [{'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2019-10-09 12:14:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2019-10-09 15:08:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 14352, 'date': '2019-10-09 16:19:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 11600, 'date': '2019-10-09 16:20:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-09 12:14:09.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure ports from pool do not reference deleted SGs/NPs

When a NP is deleted its associated SG should be deleted too.
However, when using pools, ports may have that SG assigned, not
allowing the SG deletion and consequently stoping the kuryrnetpolicy
associated object deletion -- which may cause kuryr-controller crashes
too

Closes-Bug: 1846717
Change-Id: I7ee071b32f08af567dd92bc6e081f2cb4a3b3366
(cherry picked from commit d9d81d4755f89a6d45418c009206369799a52428)
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure ports from pool do not reference deleted SGs/NPs

When a NP is deleted its associated SG should be deleted too.
However, when using pools, ports may have that SG assigned, not
allowing the SG deletion and consequently stoping the kuryrnetpolicy
associated object deletion -- which may cause kuryr-controller crashes
too

Closes-Bug: 1846717
Change-Id: I7ee071b32f08af567dd92bc6e081f2cb4a3b3366
(cherry picked from commit d9d81d4755f89a6d45418c009206369799a52428)

commit_message:
Ensure lb sg rules are updated upon namespace label updates

This patch ensures lb sg rules are updated when NPs reference to
namespace labels through namespace selectors. The affected svc
will be updated after namespace label is updated and due to that it
either starts or stops being referenced by the NP.

Closes-Bug: 1845977
Change-Id: I2d454f387676201066decce9f99d2f59b1ff6a66
(cherry picked from commit 232509ee66a43a94418cf28b59bca0d879b01b65)

commit_message:
tox: Stop overriding the 'install_command'

This is not encouraged by infra (particularly mordred and smcginnis)
since it's less obvious and easy to miss.

Change-Id: Ieb4ab13cf8ca5683fcd7b18ed669e8a26659bff1
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
trivial: Remove unused API sample template

The sample template is available in the 'os-available-zone' directory
('../os-availability-zone/availability-zone-detail-resp.json.tpl') so it
looks like this was a mistake.

Change-Id: I8c112bf930f5868680ba6f7be80ec7d8a7017e4b
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add Tempest gate job for stable/train

Now we have stable/train branch ready for devstack
and so does for all service projects.

This commit adds the Tempest testing for stable/train
by adding new jobs running on stable/train version of
openstack.

Change-Id: I0ea8008ad0ef18b9e45c41f9ba40a70fd6d57b6a

commit_message:
fixed_configured=True when Add/Remove port IPs

When updating a port with the fixed_ips request the
fixed_configured argument should be set to true when
calling _ipam_get_subnets() so that all subnets are
returned if host is not set.

Otherwise the ip allocation will be deffered and an
empty list of possible subnets for the port is
returned. Which in turn led to raising an error that
the network requires subnets to allocate an IP
address.

Closes-Bug: #1844124
Change-Id: I2e690ea0cf5fa0614e39be2b0e83afad3daa7f48
(cherry picked from commit def8e95aad1e4588c369d537ee66234245eefdf6)

commit_message:
fixed_configured=True when Add/Remove port IPs

When updating a port with the fixed_ips request the
fixed_configured argument should be set to true when
calling _ipam_get_subnets() so that all subnets are
returned if host is not set.

Otherwise the ip allocation will be deffered and an
empty list of possible subnets for the port is
returned. Which in turn led to raising an error that
the network requires subnets to allocate an IP
address.

Closes-Bug: #1844124
Change-Id: I2e690ea0cf5fa0614e39be2b0e83afad3daa7f48
(cherry picked from commit def8e95aad1e4588c369d537ee66234245eefdf6)

one or more security groups had no rules it failed

Closes-Bug: #1840465
Co-Authored-By: Tobias Urdin <tobias.urdin@binero.se>

commit_message:
Fix listing security groups when no rules

When listing security groups in the dashboard and
one or more security groups had no rules it failed
because python throws a KeyError.

This commit changes the neutron API wrapper in horizon
to ensure ensure rule information in SG always exists.

commit_message:
Use "interface" option for monasca endpoint discovery

The "interface" option was ignored for endpoint discovery. This was leading to
unexpected behaviour.

Story: 2006694
Task: 36994

commit_message:
Bump diskimage-builder minimum to 2.24.0

There was a bug[1] in diskimage-builder when using pypi mirrors
if the host doesn't have "python" available DIB will fail.
So, I am going to bump the requirements minimum in Octavia for
diskimage-builder to be the minimum version with this fix.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/diskimage-builder/+bug/1577105

Change-Id: If0ff2a855ad5b9d9ef3742ad0596c97a6dbf81ed

commit_message:
Configure monasca-ui settings in Horizon dir

The default and preferred way of modifying the settings of Horizon
plugin is to add a configuration file to
openstack_dashboard/local/local_settings.d/ directory. For that to work
we should use the settings from django.conf.settings and not from
monitoring.config.local_settings.

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/horizon/latest/configuration/settings.html

Story: 2006556
Task: 36645

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/682321
Change-Id: I718b51ce94b09bb547f03686831c3b1ac1721399
(cherry picked from commit 3f31ba407b016942f7ae4f30acd451e5f08962a6)

[{'created': '2019-10-08 18:23:48.000000000', 'message': "Privatize and reorganize base package methods

Sem-Ver: api-break

commit_message:
Privatize and reorganize base package methods

On the theory that they aren't and shouldn't be used, the following
methods are removed from the public interface of the base os_traits
package:

- symbolize (deleted, unused internally)
- import_submodules (deleted, replaced with appropriate call to
  _walk_submodules)

This commit also reorganizes the module to put private methods first,
public methods last; and alphabetize within those groupings.

Sem-Ver: api-break
Change-Id: Idb5613bc016743ba689c6996d39399aae774daa9

Adding quotes will be easy to consume the container startup config data already
generated by TripleO so we can run "podman exec" without bash error.

Note that now it works fine because we run the command with subprocess

commit_message:
Quote commands run by "bash" when doing podman exec

Adding quotes will be easy to consume the container startup config data already
generated by TripleO so we can run "podman exec" without bash error.

Note that now it works fine because we run the command with subprocess
and quotes seem to be maintained. The issue is when running with command
module in Ansible.

Change-Id: Ia5cad4ae1fa3c913415b9144c0d658a198e48916

seems okay, doesn't seem to break anything, but i you wanted to be truly complete you'd explain why you want such a thing in the commit message

or at least tell me, because I'm curious"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-10-04 13:09:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> explain why you want such a thing

Yeah.

I get questions (lately mainly from my downstreams) about traits, and one of them asked for an explanation of the taxonomy/nomenclature/hierarchy. I had thought there was already some easy way to visualize that, but found there wasn't. I started to roll a one-off and realized it would share a bunch of code we already had for generating the trait strings. One thing led to another, and nine months later..."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-10-08 14:21:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Main issue is whether we're breaking an API contract or not. Also not a huge fan of adding yet more stuff to the '__init__' file, but we're already doing it and it might be hard to avoid given how we do things here so I can hold my nose on that one"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-10-08 17:30:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Add method to visualize the os-traits tree

Add a print_tree method in the base os_traits package. This recursively
walks the repository and prints a formatted tree of short names of all
the namespaces and their traits. You can try it like this:

  python -c 'import os_traits; os_traits.print_tree()'

Here's an abbreviated subset of the output:

   COMPUTE:
      DEVICE_TAGGING, TRUSTED_CERTS
      GRAPHICS:
         MODEL_CIRRUS, MODEL_GOP, MODEL_NONE, MODEL_QXL, MODEL_VGA, MODEL_VIRTIO, MODEL_VMVGA, MODEL_XEN
   HW:
      CPU:
         HYPERTHREADING
         AMD:
            SEV
         PPC64LE:
            POWER8, POWER9
      NUMA:
         ROOT
   MISC:
      SHARES_VIA_AGGREGATE
   STORAGE:
      DISK:
         HDD, SSD

Change-Id: I6309501f10544f468bb694361c845a393a9491cf

be less hairy than Ib31ba2cbff0ebb22503172d8801b6e0c3d2aa68a.

Closes-Bug: #1846777

This patch has been started as solution of bug, but finally an
alternative solution has been followed without the involving
of this repo.

Therefore, this path could be stand as an improvement for future use.

Making the filesystem directory configurable, we are able to store the
image in the different directory or a new path under
glance_system_user_home, which new directory name or path could be
defined in the scenario as a new variable like other related
variables without any impact on glance role.

commit_message:
Turn the filesystem directory to be configurable

Update the ownership of the directory about NFS mount point(s).

This patch could be also stand as an improvement for future use.

Making the filesystem directory configurable, we are able to store
the image in the different directory (or in a new path) under
glance_system_user_home repo, which is able to be configured
dynamically, for instance, via deployment of a scenario.

Change-Id: I7403ac9bd85ea3ed149e13cb57c51039602f6ba1
Signed-off-by: Panagiotis Karalis <pkaralis@intracom-telecom.com>

commit_message:
Add nova placement to placement migration

In order to facilitate the nova placement -> extracted placement
migration, while keeping the services up for as long as possible,
we combine the two groups for the load balancer configuration on
the first pass, and pass the appropriate flag for the openstack
playbook to handle the migration. Once it's all done, we re-run
the haproxy playbook without the flag to ensure that the old nova
placement backends are removed.

We also remove haproxy_nova_placement_whitelist_networks as it is
no longer used anywhere.

Change-Id: I85e9182e7c4fe9477d30dd16b4132c1645205cce

commit_message:
Remove ovn specific logic for octavia

We probably should not have the ovn neutron driver specific
logic here. This deprecates and ignores 'neutron_driver'
parameter.

Change-Id: I9ba293d6a245ee875bf273d116baf64e44d0a554
Closes-Bug: #1839436
(cherry picked from commit 517eea74811fa5e61ea6010a620ffb50d207844b)

subject: Standardize the configuration of "oslo_messaging" section
messages:
[{'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-07-12 19:43:19.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19779, 'date': '2019-07-13 08:26:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-13 08:45:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

While I like the change in principles, I don't think it's the right direction for k-a. We aim to not handle every little bit of configuration. This "feature" was largely undocumented (and really remains as such after this - it only has a shallow introductory release note) so I don't think we should "fix" it this way.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-13 08:47:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-2

(-2 to override Chason's +2 before I am convinced we want to patch it this way)"}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-07-13 13:18:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> While I like the change in principles, I don't think it's the right
 > direction for k-a. We aim to not handle every little bit of
 > configuration. This "feature" was largely undocumented (and really
 > remains as such after this - it only has a shallow introductory
 > release note) so I don't think we should "fix" it this way.

I do understand what you are saying with respect to externalizing everything single configurations that might be out there in components that Kolla-ansible configured. However, I do disagree with you on this proposal.

I am not introducing anything new here. The parameter was already there, but badly misdefined. Moreover, the parameter has two cases, and the second case ('basic' messaging format) was not handled. I am just completing and making an already existing feature to comply with the system it is targeted to.

What I think we cannot do, is to leave something buggy out there, with a message that we have that bug because when this was developed Keystone was not properly documented.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-13 14:06:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> I am not introducing anything new here. The parameter was already
 > there, but badly misdefined. Moreover, the parameter has two cases,
 > and the second case ('basic' messaging format) was not handled. I
 > am just completing and making an already existing feature to comply
 > with the system it is targeted to.

I disagree. You change the defaults - we defaulted to not running notifications (and 'basic' was not in consideration at all).

Also note that setting 'basic' there is irrelevant because there is no messaging driver enabled for notifications if CADF is disabled.

Better deprecate this undocumented "feature" and remove it in a future release - only people studying source code would have found it anyway.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-07-13 14:22:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > I am not introducing anything new here. The parameter was already
 > > there, but badly misdefined. Moreover, the parameter has two
 > cases,
 > > and the second case ('basic' messaging format) was not handled. I
 > > am just completing and making an already existing feature to
 > comply
 > > with the system it is targeted to.
 > 
 > I disagree. You change the defaults - we defaulted to not running
 > notifications (and 'basic' was not in consideration at all).
 > 
 > Also note that setting 'basic' there is irrelevant because there is
 > no messaging driver enabled for notifications if CADF is disabled.
 > 
 > Better deprecate this undocumented "feature" and remove it in a
 > future release - only people studying source code would have found
 > it anyway.

Where is this documented? That we are disabling Keystone notification by default in kolla-ansible? We assumed when checking the available options that CADF was not used, but basic was configured as the default by Kolla-ansible.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-13 15:08:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Where is this documented? That we are disabling Keystone
 > notification by default in kolla-ansible? We assumed when checking
 > the available options that CADF was not used, but basic was
 > configured as the default by Kolla-ansible.

As I've already said - it is not documented. Please note that keystone's default is to *not* post notifications (while the default format is CADF as soon as you enable the driver without changing the format). K-a simply did not enable them. Stating that k-a disabled them is against truth."}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-07-13 17:54:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > Where is this documented? That we are disabling Keystone
 > > notification by default in kolla-ansible? We assumed when
 > checking
 > > the available options that CADF was not used, but basic was
 > > configured as the default by Kolla-ansible.
 > 
 > As I've already said - it is not documented. Please note that
 > keystone's default is to *not* post notifications (while the
 > default format is CADF as soon as you enable the driver without
 > changing the format). K-a simply did not enable them. Stating that
 > k-a disabled them is against the truth.

We have different perspectives, which is ok. I still disagree with you though.

Having said that, what do you propose then? I see three options:
* option 1 -- we can use the PR as is;
* option 2 -- we can remove the "feature" (enable_cadf_notifications) in kolla-ansible to configure CADF notification format;
* option 3 -- do nothing (abandon this PR), and leave things as they are.

Do you have other alternatives that we might be able to discuss and agree on?'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-07-13 17:57:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-13 18:45:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> We have different perspectives, which is ok. I still disagree with
 > you though.
 > 
 > Having said that, what do you propose then? I see three options:
 > * option 1 -- we can use the PR as is;
 > * option 2 -- we can remove the "feature" (enable_cadf_notifications)
 > in kolla-ansible to configure CADF notification format;
 > * option 3 -- do nothing (abandon this PR), and leave things as
 > they are.
 > 
 > Do you have other alternatives that we might be able to discuss and
 > agree on?

It's option 2 for me. But we need to add a deprecation note for the stein release in case someone actually used that hidden parameter and remove possibly in train (since it is trivial to handle this for op).

PS: We would have to add a relevant upgrade note anyway for option 1 which changes behavior.'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-07-14 01:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-07-15 19:19:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > We have different perspectives, which is ok. I still disagree
 > with
 > > you though.
 > >

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-07-17 12:08:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> That would make sense to me, but I haven't spent a huge amount of time with keystone > notifications. Are they normally published to ceilometer?

They are not necessarily published in Ceilometer, right? They are published in the "notification.info" queue (by default), and Ceilometer consumes one type of messages published in the "notification.info" queue by default. 

Barbican has a lister for Keystone messages also, and that is how we discovered this problem. Barbican has another issue; it does not define the type of messages it consumes for Oslo. Therefore, it consumes everything, which has an impact on Ceilometer, because Ceilometer starts to loose/miss events.

> If we remove enable_cadf_notifications then we would be removing the ability 
> to control whether keystone notifications are enabled.

Yes, but this parameter is a bit misleading in my opinion. Whenever I read "enable_cadf_notifications", I expect that when it has the value "no" to enable the alternative for CADF, which is basic, but it does not do that.

After digging a bit more, we took a step back to discuss and check things internally. The concept/idea; we do understand that the goal of Kolla (and Kolla-ansible) is not to externalize every single configuration, but to create a running instance of OpenStack. The issue is with the word "basic" here. For us, a "basic" deployment must send events to the event bus for every single project by default. That is what we were expecting, but that is not what happens now. For instance, after checking, we see that there are other projects (roles) with the same problem. 

There are projects (roles) such as (vitrage, murano, designate, and so on) that have hardcoded "driver = messagingv2"; some others (magnum, senlin, sahara, and so on), will enable "driver = messagingv2" if "enable_ceilometer" is "True"; others use the approach as Nova, which enables the driver to send message if there are topics defined as "enabled"; and, last, but not least, there are roles (e.g. Keystone) that do not set any driver.

It seems that we need to define a standard to deal with this configuration across these different roles. We liked the idea to do as we have for Nova right now. We are willing to do the work to apply this "standard method" (something similar to what we have in Nova) across all roles that are not yet using the same approach, if you guys agree. 

What do you guys think?'}, {'account_id': 30491, 'date': '2019-07-17 14:20:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Can we break this apart into multiple patches? One would do just what the commit message says - standardise the section. It should be a noop in terms of config changes. #notification_control_exchanges = dns
#notification_control_exchanges = ironic
#notification_control_exchanges = aodh

https://docs.openstack.org/ceilometer/latest/configuration/

If there are services not in that list and we *know* that they produce notifications, we could add a per-service flag (like the new keystone one) to enable notifications. Hey guys, here go my investigating with respect of projects that use and do not use the oslo messaging system:

* Projects that use ``oslo_messaging_notifications``:
** Barbican: https://docs.openstack.org/barbican/latest/sample_config.html
** Blazar: https://docs.openstack.org/blazar/latest/configuration/samples/blazar-conf.html
** Congress: https://docs.openstack.org/congress/latest/configuration/samples/congress.html
** Cyborg: https://docs.openstack.org/cyborg/latest/configuration/sample_config.html
** Designate: https://docs.openstack.org/designate/latest/admin/samples/config.html
** Heat: https://docs.openstack.org/heat/latest/configuration/sample_config.html
** Ironic-inspector: https://docs.openstack.org/ironic-inspector/latest/configuration/sample-config.html
** Ironic: https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/configuration/sample-config.html
** Keystone: https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/configuration/samples/keystone-conf.html
** Magnum: https://docs.openstack.org/magnum/latest/configuration/sample-config.html
** Manila: I did not find a sample of "manila.conf" online. However, I executed the steps here: https://github.com/openstack/manila/blob/master/etc/manila/README.manila.conf, and the configuration file generated in "etc/manila/manila.conf.sample" had a section called ``oslo_messaging_notifications``. Also, checking the code I see that it uses the object "messaging.Notifier" from oslo messaging.
** Mistral: I did not find much information here https://docs.openstack.org/mistral/latest/configuration/config-guide.html. However, I download Mistral code, and I checked the "etc/mistral.conf.sample" file, and it has the ``oslo_messaging_notifications`` section.
** Murano: https://docs.openstack.org/murano/latest/configuration/sample_config.html
** Nova: https://docs.openstack.org/nova/latest/configuration/sample-config.html
** Octavia: https://docs.openstack.org/octavia/latest/configuration/configref.html#oslo-messaging-notifications
** Sahara: https://docs.openstack.org/sahara/latest/admin/configuration-guide.html
** Searchlight: I checked the code at https://github.com/openstack/searchlight, and it does use the oslo messaging system
** Senlin: I checked the code at https://github.com/openstack/senlin, and it uses the oslo messaging system
** Tacker: https://docs.openstack.org/tacker/latest/configuration/
** Trove-conductor: https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/etc/trove/trove-conductor.conf.sample
** Trove-taskmanager: https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/etc/trove/trove-taskmanager.conf.sample
** Trove: https://github.com/openstack/trove/blob/master/etc/trove/trove.conf.sample
** Vitrage: https://docs.openstack.org/vitrage/latest/configuration/ and https://github.com/openstack/vitrage
** Watcher: I checked the code at https://github.com/openstack/watcher
** Zun: https://docs.openstack.org/zun/latest/configuration/sample-config.html

* Projects that do not use ``oslo_messaging_notifications``:
** Karbor: https://docs.openstack.org/karbor/latest/configuration/karbor.html#
** Qinling: Checked the code at https://github.com/openstack/qinling, and it does not use the oslo messaging notification system
** Solum: I hecked the code at https://github.com/openstack/solum, and it does not use the oslo messaging notification system


* not sure? However, I would expect them to use somehow the queueing system.
** neutron_hyperv_agent.conf.j2: Checking here: https://docs.openstack.org/ocata/config-reference/networking/networking_options_reference.html#cloudbase-hyper-v-agent-configuration-options, it seems that we do not have this option.
** nova_hyperv.conf.j2: I checked at https://docs.openstack.org/nova/pike/admin/configuration/hypervisor-hyper-v.html, but I could not find anything relating to oslo messaging sections

I will now revert the changed I applied in Karbor, Qinling, and Solum. After this PR gets merged, I will then open another PR to remove those sections from them (the projects that do not use oslo messaging system).'}, {'account_id': 28356, 'date': '2019-08-07 20:21:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 18.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-08-08 09:39:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 18:

I don't think checking for the presence of that section is enough. Any service that depends on oslo.messaging will have oslo_messaging_notifications section, but that does not mean that they generate notifications.

I think a fairly good indicator might be the use of the 'get_notification_transport' function in oslo_messaging. http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=get_notification_transport&i=nope&files=&repos=. revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-12 19:43:19.000000000', 'message': "Fix bug when configuring Keystone events format

By default Kolla-ansible defines 'enable_cadf_notifications'
as 'no'. This variable is used to enable/disable CADF format
in Keystone. However, the default of Keystone is 'CADF'.
Therefore, Kolla-ansible will configure Keystone without
setting the oslo.messaging driver as messagingv2. This
will create a configuration that does not publish events
in RabbitMQ.

This change (PR) is introducing a few things:
* Moving the definition of 'enable_cadf_notifications' to
Keystone role as it is only used there
* Changing the default value defined to 'yes' because that is
the default behavior in Keystone. Keystone uses CADF format by
Default.
* Add an else condition in Keystone.conf template. When CADF is
not enabled, we need to explicitly set the format as 'basic'.

Change-Id: I88bdb004814f37c81c9a9c4e5e491fac69f6f202
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>
"}, {'created': '2019-07-13 17:57:31.000000000', 'message': "Fix bug when configuring Keystone events format

By default Kolla-ansible defines 'enable_cadf_notifications'
as 'no'. This variable is used to enable/disable CADF format

Therefore, Kolla-ansible will configure Keystone without
setting the oslo.messaging driver as messagingv2. This
will create a configuration that does not publish events
in RabbitMQ.

This change (PR) is introducing a few things:
* Moving the definition of 'enable_cadf_notifications' to
Keystone role as it is only used there
* Changing the default value defined to 'yes' because that is
the default behavior in Keystone. Keystone uses CADF format by
Default.
* Add an else condition in Keystone.conf template. When CADF is
not enabled, we need to explicitly set the format as 'basic'.

Change-Id: I88bdb004814f37c81c9a9c4e5e491fac69f6f202
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>
"}, {'created': '2019-07-26 12:27:32.000000000', 'message': 'Standardize the configuration of "oslo_messaging" section

After all of the discussions we had on
"https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2", I studied all projects that
have an "oslo_messaging" section. Afterwards, I applied the same method
that is already used in "oslo_messaging" section in Nova, Cinder, and
others. This guarantees that we have a consistent method to
enable/disable notifications across projects based on components (e.g.
Ceilometer) being enabled or disabled. Here follows the list of
components, and the respective changed I did.

* Aodh:
It was already properly configured.

* Congress:
The topic is hard-coded "congress-validator-agent" or
"congress-service-<serviceID>". Therefore, we need to set the driver.
Otherwise, as a minimum working Congress setup we would not have the
notifications.

* Karbor:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Cinder:
It was already properly configured.

* Octavia:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Heat:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Ceilometer:
Ceilometer publishes some messages in the rabbitMQ. However, the
default driver is "messagingv2", and not ''(empty) as defined in Oslo;
these configurations are defined in ceilometer/publisher/messaging.py.
Therefore, we do not need to do anything for the
"oslo_messaging_notifications" section in Ceilometer

* Tacker:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Neutron:
It was already properly configured.

* Qinling
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Nova
It was already properly configured. However, we found another issue
with its configuration. Kolla-ansible does not configure nova
notifications as it should. If 'searchlight' is not installed (enabled)
the 'notification_format' should be 'unversioned'. The default is
'both'; so nova will send a notification to the queue
versioned_notifications; but that queue has no consumer when
'searchlight' is disabled. In our case, the queue got 511k messages.
The huge amount of "stuck" messages made the Rabbitmq cluster
unstable.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1478274

* Nova_hyperv:
I added the same configurations as in Nova project.

* Solum
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Vitrage
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Searchlight
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Ironic
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Glance
It was already properly configured.

* Trove
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Blazar
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Sahara
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Watcher
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Barbican
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others. I also added a configuration to 'keystone_notifications'
section. Barbican needs its own queue to capture events from Keystone.
Otherwise, it has an impact on Ceilometer and other systems that are
connected to the "notifications" default queue.

* Keystone
Keystone is the system that triggered this work with the discussions
that followed on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2. After a long
discussion, we agreed to apply the same approach that we have in Nova,
Cinder and other systems in Keystone. That is what we did. Moreover, we
introduce a new topic "barbican_notifications" when barbican is
enabled. We also removed the "variable" enable_cadf_notifications, as
it is obsolete, and the default in Keystone is CADF.

* Mistral:
It was hardcoded "noop" as the driver. However, that does not seem a
good practice. Instead, I applied the same standard of using the driver
and pushing to "notifications" queue if Ceilometer is enabled.

* Cyborg:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Murano
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Senlin
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Manila
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Zun
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Designate
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Magnum
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

Change-Id: I88bdb004814f37c81c9a9c4e5e491fac69f6f202
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

Keystone is the system that triggered this work with the discussions
that followed on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2. After a long
discussion, we agreed to apply the same approach that we have in Nova,
Cinder and other systems in Keystone. That is what we did. Moreover, we
introduce a new topic "barbican_notifications" when barbican is
enabled. We also removed the "variable" enable_cadf_notifications, as
it is obsolete, and the default in Keystone is CADF.

* Mistral:
It was hardcoded "noop" as the driver. However, that does not seem a
good practice. Instead, I applied the same standard of using the driver
and pushing to "notifications" queue if Ceilometer is enabled.

* Cyborg:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Murano
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Senlin
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Manila
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Zun

'}, {'created': '2019-07-26 16:30:54.000000000', 'message': 'Standardize the configuration of "oslo_messaging" section

After all of the discussions we had on
"https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2", I studied all projects that
have an "oslo_messaging" section. Afterwards, I applied the same method
that is already used in "oslo_messaging" section in Nova, Cinder, and
others. This guarantees that we have a consistent method to
enable/disable notifications across projects based on components (e.g.
Ceilometer) being enabled or disabled. Here follows the list of
components, and the respective changes I did.

* Aodh:
It was already properly configured.

* Congress:
The topic is hard-coded "congress-validator-agent" or
"congress-service-<serviceID>". Therefore, we need to set the driver.
Otherwise, as a minimum working Congress setup we would not have the
notifications.

* Karbor:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Cinder:
It was already properly configured.

* Octavia:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Heat:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Ceilometer:
Ceilometer publishes some messages in the rabbitMQ. However, the
default driver is "messagingv2", and not ''(empty) as defined in Oslo;
these configurations are defined in ceilometer/publisher/messaging.py.
Therefore, we do not need to do anything for the
"oslo_messaging_notifications" section in Ceilometer

* Tacker:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Neutron:
It was already properly configured.

* Qinling
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Nova
It was already properly configured. However, we found another issue
with its configuration. Kolla-ansible does not configure nova
notifications as it should. If 'searchlight' is not installed (enabled)
the 'notification_format' should be 'unversioned'. The default is
'both'; so nova will send a notification to the queue
versioned_notifications; but that queue has no consumer when
'searchlight' is disabled. In our case, the queue got 511k messages.
The huge amount of "stuck" messages made the Rabbitmq cluster
unstable.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1478274
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1665449

* Nova_hyperv:
I added the same configurations as in Nova project.

* Solum
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Vitrage
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Searchlight
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Ironic
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Glance
It was already properly configured.

* Trove
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Blazar
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Sahara
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Watcher
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Barbican
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others. I also added a configuration to 'keystone_notifications'
section. Barbican needs its own queue to capture events from Keystone.
Otherwise, it has an impact on Ceilometer and other systems that are
connected to the "notifications" default queue.

* Keystone
Keystone is the system that triggered this work with the discussions
that followed on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2. After a long
discussion, we agreed to apply the same approach that we have in Nova,
Cinder and other systems in Keystone. That is what we did. Moreover, we
introduce a new topic "barbican_notifications" when barbican is
enabled. We also removed the "variable" enable_cadf_notifications, as
it is obsolete, and the default in Keystone is CADF.

* Mistral:
It was hardcoded "noop" as the driver. However, that does not seem a
good practice. Instead, I applied the same standard of using the driver
and pushing to "notifications" queue if Ceilometer is enabled.

* Cyborg:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Murano
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Senlin
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Manila
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Zun
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Designate
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Magnum
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

Change-Id: I88bdb004814f37c81c9a9c4e5e491fac69f6f202
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

introduce a new topic "barbican_notifications" when barbican is
enabled. We also removed the "variable" enable_cadf_notifications, as
it is obsolete, and the default in Keystone is CADF.

* Mistral:
It was hardcoded "noop" as the driver. However, that does not seem a
good practice. Instead, I applied the same standard of using the driver
and pushing to "notifications" queue if Ceilometer is enabled.

* Cyborg:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

'}, {'created': '2019-08-05 17:26:31.000000000', 'message': 'Standardize the configuration of "oslo_messaging" section

After all of the discussions we had on
"https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2", I studied all projects that
have an "oslo_messaging" section. Afterwards, I applied the same method
that is already used in "oslo_messaging" section in Nova, Cinder, and
others. This guarantees that we have a consistent method to
enable/disable notifications across projects based on components (e.g.
Ceilometer) being enabled or disabled. Here follows the list of
components, and the respective changes I did.

* Aodh:
It was already properly configured.

* Congress:
The topic is hard-coded "congress-validator-agent" or
"congress-service-<serviceID>". Therefore, we need to set the driver.
Otherwise, as a minimum working Congress setup we would not have the
notifications.

* Karbor:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Cinder:
It was already properly configured.

* Octavia:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Heat:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Ceilometer:
Ceilometer publishes some messages in the rabbitMQ. However, the
default driver is "messagingv2", and not ''(empty) as defined in Oslo;
these configurations are defined in ceilometer/publisher/messaging.py.
Therefore, we do not need to do anything for the
"oslo_messaging_notifications" section in Ceilometer

* Tacker:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Neutron:
It was already properly configured.

* Qinling
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Nova
It was already properly configured. However, we found another issue
with its configuration. Kolla-ansible does not configure nova
notifications as it should. If 'searchlight' is not installed (enabled)
the 'notification_format' should be 'unversioned'. The default is
'both'; so nova will send a notification to the queue
versioned_notifications; but that queue has no consumer when
'searchlight' is disabled. In our case, the queue got 511k messages.
The huge amount of "stuck" messages made the Rabbitmq cluster
unstable.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1478274
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1665449

* Nova_hyperv:
I added the same configurations as in Nova project.

* Solum
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Vitrage
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Searchlight
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Ironic
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Glance
It was already properly configured.

* Trove
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Blazar
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Sahara
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Watcher
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Barbican
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others. I also added a configuration to 'keystone_notifications'
section. Barbican needs its own queue to capture events from Keystone.
Otherwise, it has an impact on Ceilometer and other systems that are
connected to the "notifications" default queue.

* Keystone
Keystone is the system that triggered this work with the discussions
that followed on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2. After a long
discussion, we agreed to apply the same approach that we have in Nova,
Cinder and other systems in Keystone. That is what we did. Moreover, we
introduce a new topic "barbican_notifications" when barbican is
enabled. We also removed the "variable" enable_cadf_notifications, as
it is obsolete, and the default in Keystone is CADF.

* Mistral:
It was hardcoded "noop" as the driver. However, that does not seem a
good practice. Instead, I applied the same standard of using the driver
and pushing to "notifications" queue if Ceilometer is enabled.

* Cyborg:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Murano
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Senlin
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Manila
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Zun
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Designate
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Magnum
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

Closes-Bug: https://bugs.launchpad.net/kolla-ansible/+bug/1838985

Change-Id: I88bdb004814f37c81c9a9c4e5e491fac69f6f202
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

introduce a new topic "barbican_notifications" when barbican is
enabled. We also removed the "variable" enable_cadf_notifications, as
it is obsolete, and the default in Keystone is CADF.

* Mistral:
It was hardcoded "noop" as the driver. However, that does not seem a
good practice. Instead, I applied the same standard of using the driver
and pushing to "notifications" queue if Ceilometer is enabled.

* Cyborg:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

'}, {'created': '2019-08-07 12:25:18.000000000', 'message': 'Standardize the configuration of "oslo_messaging" section

After all of the discussions we had on
"https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2", I studied all projects that
have an "oslo_messaging" section. Afterwards, I applied the same method
that is already used in "oslo_messaging" section in Nova, Cinder, and
others. This guarantees that we have a consistent method to
enable/disable notifications across projects based on components (e.g.
Ceilometer) being enabled or disabled. Here follows the list of
components, and the respective changes I did.

* Aodh:
It was already properly configured.

* Congress:
The topic is hard-coded "congress-validator-agent" or
"congress-service-<serviceID>". Therefore, we need to set the driver.
Otherwise, as a minimum working Congress setup we would not have the
notifications.

* Karbor:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Cinder:
It was already properly configured.

* Octavia:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Heat:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Ceilometer:
Ceilometer publishes some messages in the rabbitMQ. However, the
default driver is "messagingv2", and not ''(empty) as defined in Oslo;
these configurations are defined in ceilometer/publisher/messaging.py.
Therefore, we do not need to do anything for the
"oslo_messaging_notifications" section in Ceilometer

* Tacker:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Neutron:
It was already properly configured.

* Qinling
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Nova
It was already properly configured. However, we found another issue
with its configuration. Kolla-ansible does not configure nova
notifications as it should. If 'searchlight' is not installed (enabled)
the 'notification_format' should be 'unversioned'. The default is
'both'; so nova will send a notification to the queue
versioned_notifications; but that queue has no consumer when
'searchlight' is disabled. In our case, the queue got 511k messages.
The huge amount of "stuck" messages made the Rabbitmq cluster
unstable.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1478274
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1665449

* Nova_hyperv:
I added the same configurations as in Nova project.

* Solum
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Vitrage
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Searchlight
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Ironic
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Glance
It was already properly configured.

* Trove
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Blazar
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Sahara
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Watcher
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Barbican
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others. I also added a configuration to 'keystone_notifications'
section. Barbican needs its own queue to capture events from Keystone.
Otherwise, it has an impact on Ceilometer and other systems that are
connected to the "notifications" default queue.

* Keystone
Keystone is the system that triggered this work with the discussions
that followed on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2. After a long
discussion, we agreed to apply the same approach that we have in Nova,
Cinder and other systems in Keystone. That is what we did. Moreover, we
introduce a new topic "barbican_notifications" when barbican is
enabled. We also removed the "variable" enable_cadf_notifications, as
it is obsolete, and the default in Keystone is CADF.

* Mistral:
It was hardcoded "noop" as the driver. However, that does not seem a
good practice. Instead, I applied the same standard of using the driver
and pushing to "notifications" queue if Ceilometer is enabled.

* Cyborg:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Murano
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Senlin
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Manila
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Zun
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Designate
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Magnum
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

Closes-Bug: #1838985

Change-Id: I88bdb004814f37c81c9a9c4e5e491fac69f6f202
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

commit_message:
Standardize the configuration of "oslo_messaging" section

After all of the discussions we had on
"https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2", I studied all projects that
have an "oslo_messaging" section. Afterwards, I applied the same method
that is already used in "oslo_messaging" section in Nova, Cinder, and
others. This guarantees that we have a consistent method to
enable/disable notifications across projects based on components (e.g.
Ceilometer) being enabled or disabled. Here follows the list of
components, and the respective changes I did.

* Aodh:
The section is declared, but it is not used. Therefore, it will
be removed in an upcomming PR.

* Congress:
The section is declared, but it is not used. Therefore, it will
be removed in an upcomming PR.

* Cinder:
It was already properly configured.

* Octavia:
The section is declared, but it is not used. Therefore, it will
be removed in an upcomming PR.

* Heat:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Ceilometer:
Ceilometer publishes some messages in the rabbitMQ. However, the
default driver is "messagingv2", and not ''(empty) as defined in Oslo;
these configurations are defined in ceilometer/publisher/messaging.py.
Therefore, we do not need to do anything for the
"oslo_messaging_notifications" section in Ceilometer

* Tacker:
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Neutron:
It was already properly configured.

* Nova
It was already properly configured. However, we found another issue
with its configuration. Kolla-ansible does not configure nova
notifications as it should. If 'searchlight' is not installed (enabled)
the 'notification_format' should be 'unversioned'. The default is
'both'; so nova will send a notification to the queue
versioned_notifications; but that queue has no consumer when
'searchlight' is disabled. In our case, the queue got 511k messages.
The huge amount of "stuck" messages made the Rabbitmq cluster
unstable.

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1478274
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ceilometer/+bug/1665449

* Nova_hyperv:
I added the same configurations as in Nova project.

* Vitrage
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Searchlight
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Ironic
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Glance
It was already properly configured.

* Trove
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Blazar
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Sahara
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Watcher
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Barbican
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in Cinder, Nova,
and others. I also added a configuration to 'keystone_notifications'
section. Barbican needs its own queue to capture events from Keystone.
Otherwise, it has an impact on Ceilometer and other systems that are
connected to the "notifications" default queue.

* Keystone
Keystone is the system that triggered this work with the discussions
that followed on https://review.opendev.org/#/c/670626/2. After a long
discussion, we agreed to apply the same approach that we have in Nova,
Cinder and other systems in Keystone. That is what we did. Moreover, we
introduce a new topic "barbican_notifications" when barbican is
enabled. We also removed the "variable" enable_cadf_notifications, as
it is obsolete, and the default in Keystone is CADF.

* Mistral:
It was hardcoded "noop" as the driver. However, that does not seem a
good practice. Instead, I applied the same standard of using the driver
and pushing to "notifications" queue if Ceilometer is enabled.

* Cyborg:
I created a mechanism similar to what we have in AODH, Cinder, Nova,
and others.

* Murano
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Senlin
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Manila
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Zun
The section is declared, but it is not used. Therefore, it will
be removed in an upcomming PR.

* Designate
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

* Magnum
It was already using a similar scheme; I just modified it a little bit
to be the same as we have in all other components

Closes-Bug: #1838985

Change-Id: I88bdb004814f37c81c9a9c4e5e491fac69f6f202
Signed-off-by: Rafael Weingärtner <rafael@apache.org>

Failures in the gate suggest that it is now somehow possible for the
Glance image created by a snapshot to appear to have been created even
while the Nova server remains in a state like 'image_uploading'. Servers
in this state cannot be rebuilt (to restore a snapshot). To ensure that
the snapshot has actually completed before the resource is marked
SNAPSHOT_COMPLETE, check the task state of the server as well as the
state of the snapshot image in Glance.

commit_message:
Don't mark snapshot complete while task in progress

Failures in the gate suggest that it is now somehow possible for the
Glance image created by a snapshot to appear to have been created even
while the Nova server remains in a state like 'image_uploading'. Servers
in this state cannot be rebuilt (to restore a snapshot). To ensure that
the snapshot has actually completed before the resource is marked
SNAPSHOT_COMPLETE, check the task state of the server as well as the
state of the snapshot image in Glance.

Change-Id: I2b5cddcbeab849054d84501dfcec48442f3666d3
Co-Authored-By: Rico Lin <rico.lin.guanyu@gmail.com>
Task: 36964

LGTM, needs PTL+1'}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-10-04 12:49:50.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from charms-train to charms-train-placement'}, {'account_id': 935, 'date': '2019-10-04 13:55:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2019-10-05 14:15:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Note that you will start with an empty repository. Your very first
patch needs to setup the repository and add all infrastructure so that
the jobs pass (this can be done with a cookiecutter project).

Also, you can import an existing repository including it's history if
you have one. Once the repository is created, importing is not
possible anymore, changes will have to go through the normal review
process.

If you have a lot of history to import, please use the upstream field
instead of creating a repository and then pushing the patches one at a
time. Pushing a large number of related patches all at one time causes
the CI infrastructure to slow down, which impacts work on all of the
other projects using it. After repo creation the infra team will not
push any content to it; this is your only chance to import directly.

Please confirm that starting with an empty repo is fine."}, {'account_id': 11805, 'date': '2019-10-07 12:26:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-07 12:50:14.000000000', 'message': 'Raising minimum version of oslo.db

oslo.db was not compatible with Python 3.7 until version 4.40.0
because Python 3.7 makes "async" a keyword [1].
To prevent bad surprises, this patch increases the minumum version
required for oslo.db to 4.40.0.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/574833

Change-Id: I6b915a0b0f78690defa962be96c8ae9d35d69345
'}]
commit_message:
Raising minimum version of oslo.db

oslo.db was not compatible with Python 3.7 until version 4.40.0
because Python 3.7 makes "async" a keyword [1].
To prevent bad surprises, this patch increases the minumum version
required for oslo.db to 4.40.0.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/574833

Change-Id: I6b915a0b0f78690defa962be96c8ae9d35d69345

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-20 17:40:26.000000000', 'message': 'Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I01e85dd79a5b008c11e72b0984b8bccd915abc43
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I01e85dd79a5b008c11e72b0984b8bccd915abc43

commit_message:
Use xz instead of pxz

xz now has the threading fuction that was only previously in pxz. Switch
to the more standard package.

Change-Id: Idbf675c356d9f5c5faaf16d54c9a03afc5b8726e

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-02 13:22:59.000000000', 'message': 'Dell EMC SC: Handle the mappings of multiattached volume

For volumes attached to multiple instances, this handles
the deletion of mappings in the backend when the volume
is attached to multiple instances on the same host.

Change-Id: I33d691d1dfa835b70726bcfacf868faab52de16a
Closes-Bug: #1822229
Co-Authored-By: Sam Wan <sam_wan@emc.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-09-04 10:25:07.000000000', 'message': 'Dell EMC SC: Handle the mappings of multiattached volume

For volumes attached to multiple instances, this handles
the deletion of mappings in the backend when the volume
is attached to multiple instances on the same host.

Closes-Bug: #1822229

commit_message:
Dell EMC SC: Handle the mappings of multiattached volume

For volumes attached to multiple instances, this handles
the deletion of mappings in the backend when the volume
is attached to multiple instances on the same host.

Closes-Bug: #1822229
Co-Authored-By: Sam Wan <sam_wan@emc.com>
Change-Id: I33d691d1dfa835b70726bcfacf868faab52de16a
(cherry picked from commit 08d35b099113679eb7d343f7463d63cb6f1adbbc)

because we do need to run functional test jobs for changes to

commit_message:
Skip functional test jobs for doc redirect changes

Changes to docs to handle redirects like [1] should not
trigger functional jobs. Note that functional-irrelevant-files
does not just blindly ignore all changes to the docs/* path
because we do need to run functional test jobs for changes to
doc/notification_samples.

[1] Iad18f355a20261313ddb3dafd302ed66ebca64bc

Change-Id: I4c2cb97de1fc8e1ed80fa22680621fd4f6390cfd

subject: Support TLS priorities for pacemaker
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-10-09 06:39:31.000000000', 'message': 'Support TLS priorities for pacemaker

Introduce a PacemakerTLSPriorities parameter (which will set the
PCMK_tls_priorities config option in /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker and the
PCMK_tls_priorities variable inside the bundle. This, when set, allows
an operator to specify what kind of GNUTLS ciphers are desired for the
pacemaker control port.

Tested on both queens and stein. Via a deploy and a redeploy against
existing cloud. Observed that:
A) We got PCMK_tls_priorities inside /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker with the
value that was passed in THT
B) Containers had the following env variable set:
  "PCMK_tls_priorities=normal",

NB: cherry-pick not 100% clean (tiny conflict due to I0b2ae95563f64a21ef673e1e60889424a03fbc42
enable stonith deep_compare being merged in the meantime). Also made
sure that the firewall_rules are expressed with '.' and not with '::'
(I6f67153e04aed191acb715fe8cfa976ee2e75878 is the change that happened
later which explains the background)

(cherry-picked from commit feee059a439e16f4bc179ea007567d05ef63220f)
(cherry picked from commit 62f6287a8f7594b589a548a5465d24af070f90f5)
Depends-On: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435
Change-Id: I2a2ea8bfa4da35fa8721b14909b0968123379558
(cherry picked from commit 8a75427d691cbdbc5f2a68646245e1d0d471c94f)
'}]
commit_message:
Support TLS priorities for pacemaker

Introduce a PacemakerTLSPriorities parameter (which will set the
PCMK_tls_priorities config option in /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker and the
PCMK_tls_priorities variable inside the bundle. This, when set, allows
an operator to specify what kind of GNUTLS ciphers are desired for the
pacemaker control port.

Tested on both queens and stein. Via a deploy and a redeploy against
existing cloud. Observed that:
A) We got PCMK_tls_priorities inside /etc/sysconfig/pacemaker with the
value that was passed in THT
B) Containers had the following env variable set:
  "PCMK_tls_priorities=normal",

NB: cherry-pick not 100% clean (tiny conflict due to I0b2ae95563f64a21ef673e1e60889424a03fbc42
enable stonith deep_compare being merged in the meantime). Also made
sure that the firewall_rules are expressed with '.' and not with '::'
(I6f67153e04aed191acb715fe8cfa976ee2e75878 is the change that happened
later which explains the background)

(cherry-picked from commit feee059a439e16f4bc179ea007567d05ef63220f)
(cherry picked from commit 62f6287a8f7594b589a548a5465d24af070f90f5)
Depends-On: I703b5a429f48063474aace85bc45d948f5c91435
Change-Id: I2a2ea8bfa4da35fa8721b14909b0968123379558
(cherry picked from commit 8a75427d691cbdbc5f2a68646245e1d0d471c94f)

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I1f09052cc88a680276263b9bc4b2375483b3a1f5

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-19 21:59:44.000000000', 'message': "Avoid port group creation race

The neutron_pg_drop Porg Group is created with some ACLs to drop
all the traffic by default. This group doesn't match any Neutron
resource and it's created once the first Neutron port with
port_security enabled gets created.

A race condition exists whn the first two ports get created
simultaneously by different works as both may attempt to create
this Port Group. The result is that one of the port creations will
fail. Setting may_exist=True should avoid this race

Co-authored-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: 1838969
Change-Id: I8c1174df562a7164d4a96ce2e733279723827dcd
"}, {'created': '2019-09-19 23:01:28.000000000', 'message': "Avoid port group creation race

The neutron_pg_drop Porg Group is created with some ACLs to drop
all the traffic by default. This group doesn't match any Neutron
resource and it's created once the first Neutron port with
port_security enabled gets created.

A race condition exists whn the first two ports get created
simultaneously by different works as both may attempt to create
this Port Group. The result is that one of the port creations will
fail. Setting may_exist=True should avoid this race

Co-authored-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: 1838969
Change-Id: I8c1174df562a7164d4a96ce2e733279723827dcd
"}]
commit_message:
Avoid port group creation race

The neutron_pg_drop Porg Group is created with some ACLs to drop
all the traffic by default. This group doesn't match any Neutron
resource and it's created once the first Neutron port with
port_security enabled gets created.

A race condition exists whn the first two ports get created
simultaneously by different works as both may attempt to create
this Port Group. The result is that one of the port creations will
fail. Setting may_exist=True should avoid this race

Co-authored-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: 1838969
Change-Id: I8c1174df562a7164d4a96ce2e733279723827dcd

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:
New alembic migration to support namespaces in postgresql

We are now using drop_index to delete old constraint (name + project_id)
in namespace support migration. It works only for MySQL, for PostgreSQL
we should use drop_constraint to delete old constraint.
drop_index does not affect PostgreSQL and drop_constraint does not affect
MySQL, so we should use both for namespace support for both databases.
Added old constraint (name + project_id) deletion for
PostgreSQL with new migration.

Change-Id: I137162dd2b643b24f02799c6a13e3b0c0a8d3fb5
Closes-bug: #1838635

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/train

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/train branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I9179398f039e6b5809d9221722c1899246d3f213
